resources.string: This application is dedicated to all the nature lovers and persons willing to learn Earth’s history. It is simple enough for popular science and has enough facts to use it for the teaching purposes. Facts in this application correspond with the modern paleontological data and are backed up by only the accepted scientific articles.

Photos:
Creative Commons Zero (CC0)

If you found any errors or want to donate, or contribute towards improving this app, please contact me via email: admin@bio-matic.com

Do you wish to contribute to this app and be immortalized on the Wall of Fame? Do you have a scientific background and know any language not present here? If both answers are yes, then hit me up with an e-mail and lets make this app even greater!
Single-celled life traces, first oxygen. Photosynthesis.
Multi-celled life traces, atmospheric oxygen. Global glaciations.
Times of the large forests and insects. Pangaea formation.
Arid Earth period. Largest mass extinction in the Earth history.
Dinosaur dominance. Division of the Pangaea.
Time of the Ice Ages. Current times.

Hadean Eon – the earliest part of the Earth history, which covers times from the beginning of the formation of the Earth until the formation of the tectonic plates 4.0 billion years ago.
The landscape of the Early Hadean looked like hell. The surface was covered by volcanoes and molten rock, and the planet was constantly attacked by meteorites and comets.
The first 100 million years were too inhospitable for any kind of life, with surface temperatures of 230 degrees celsius (at the beginning even 2000 degrees), and atmospheric pressure 27 times higher than now. Earth possessed an atmosphere, but it was repeatedly lost because of frequent collisions with other space objects.
4.4 billion years ago planet began to cool; zircon discoveries provide evidences of liquid water during that time. The end of this eon is marked by the formation of the oceans and continental crust.

There is no hard proof that any life form could exist in such a harsh environment; however there are 4.1-billion-year-old findings of carbon minerals in Western Australia, which provide evidence that there could have been sustainable conditions for life. Some scientists think that life may have arisen multiple times, but was repeatedly wiped out in frequent cataclysms. The main source of organic particles – carbon meteorites – may provide evidence that life exists outside of Earth.

Archean Eon – the second huge eon in the Earth history, which covers times from the formation of the first tectonic plates 4.0 billion years ago until the Great Oxidation Event 2.5 billion years ago.\nAt the beginning of this eon, Earth’s temperature was 2-3 times higher than the today. The causes of this phenomenon were: high concentration of greenhouse gases (tens of times higher than today) and heat from the formation and growth of the planet core.\nAt that time Sun had about 70–75% of the present luminosity. By the end of this eon, Earth’s tectonics were similar to the present, and there were vast oceans of liquid water.

4.0 billion years ago, the planets of our solar system (including Earth) were heavily bombarded by large cosmic bodies for approximately 200 million years. Evidence of this event was returned to earth by the Apollo astronauts in form of lunar samples.
Extrapolating lunar cratering rates to the Earth at this time suggests the following number of craters would have formed:
1. 22,000 craters with diameters bigger than 20 km.
2. 40 craters with diameters bigger than 1000 km.
3. Several craters with diameter around 5000 km.
The main hypothesis for this cause is that the giant planets (like Jupiter, Saturn, and Neptune) underwent orbital migration, and in doing so, scattered objects in the asteroid and/or Kuiper belts into eccentric orbits, and into the path of the terrestrial planets. This event might have postponed the creation of life at the Early Archean.

Unlike in the Hadean, the existence of life during the Archean is not in doubt, although there are disputes about the time life first appeared.\nThe first solid evidence of life comes from the 3.85-billion-year-old banded iron formations found in Greenland. These formations require oxygen for their formation, and the only source of oxygen during that time was photosynthesis, so the existence of these formations is direct evidence of life.\nPossible first prokaryotes have been found in Canadian rocks that are at least 3.77 billion years old, and by judging lipid biomarkers, the first eukaryotes might have appeared by the end of the period, about 2.7 billion years ago.

Proterozoic Eon – the third large eon, which covers times just before the proliferation of complex life on Earth. The most important events of this time were the transition to an oxygenated atmosphere, several global glaciations (the Snowball Earth hypothesis), and the evolution of soft-bodied, multicellular organisms.\nThis is a hypothetical reconstruction of a Snowball Earth during the Huronian and Cryogenian glaciations.

The Great Oxidation Event was the biologically induced appearance of oxygen in Earth’s atmosphere which happened around 2.5 billion years ago. The general hypothesis states that the main cause of this event was the development of oxygenic photosynthesis in cyanobacteria.
Before this event, any free oxygen was chemically captured by dissolved iron or organic matter, but once these oxygen sinks became saturated, oxygen was free to escape into atmosphere.
Free oxygen is toxic to obligate anaerobic organisms, so this event caused their mass extinction. Additionally, oxygen reacted with atmospheric methane, greatly reducing its concentration and triggering Huronian glaciation, which lasted about 300 million years (2400–2100 mya).
These tremendous changes in Earth’s chemical interactions provided a new opportunity for biological diversification, as life adapted to tolerate and then take advantage of atmospheric oxygen. This breakthrough in metabolic evolution greatly increased the free energy supply to living organisms, allowing the creation of new, more complex morphologies.

This eon represents the evolution of life from simple to more complex forms. During the Great Oxidation Event most of the anaerobic organisms were replaced by more advanced protista and bacteria. By halfway through the eon, stromatolites saw their greatest diversity, and the ancestors of fungi diverged from the ancestors of animals. By the Ediacaran (635 mya), the first advanced, soft bodied multicellular organisms had appeared.

The Cambrian period was the first geological period of the Paleozoic era, it marked a profound change in life on Earth. Prior to the Cambrian, the majority of living organisms were small and simple. However, in the Cambrian rapid diversification occurred, in an event is known as the Cambrian Explosion. The great glaciers of the Proterozoic eon were long melted – the sea level was high, which led to large areas of the continents being flooded by warm, shallow seas ideal for sea life.\nThe Earth was generally cool during the Early Cambrian, probably due to the ancient continent of Gondwana covering the South Pole and cutting off polar ocean currents. However, average temperatures were still 7 degrees higher than today. There were likely polar ice caps and a series of glaciations, but it became warmer towards the end of the period; the glaciers retreated and eventually disappeared, and sea levels rose dramatically. This trend would continue into the Ordovician period.

The Cambrian explosion was a relatively short evolutionary event, during which 63% of all biological classes, and most of the major modern animal phyla, appeared. The most notable events were the appearance of burrowing and the diversification of skeletonized animals, which were absent or rare before the Cambrian.
Possible causes of this event:
1. Increased available oxygen.
2. Ozone formation, which decreased the deadly effects of UV rays.
3. The Snowball Earth event during the Proterozoic, which caused a mass extinction of the previous life forms, freeing up many ecological niches.
4. Increased calcium concentration in Cambrian seawater, which made it possible for marine organisms to build skeletons and hard body parts.
5. Developmental changes – appearance of self-organization and body plans triggered by the new Hox genes.
6. Changes in the food chain – appearance of coevolution, when predators and prey started “arms races”.
The Cambrian was also a period of nature experimenting with body forms, and many strange animal phenotypes appeared.

Most animal life during the Cambrian was aquatic. Arthropods were by far the most dominant animals in the ocean, and many new mineralized and burrowing animals appeared. However, unlike in modern times, most animals were still living on or near the sea floor.

The Ordovician is the second of six periods of the Paleozoic era. During this period ancient oceans separated the barren continents of Laurentia, Baltica, Siberia and Gondwana. The end of the Ordovician was one of the coldest times in Earth history. Ice covered much of the southern region of Gondwana.

Also called the Great Ordovician Biodiversification Event (GOBE), which replaced the distinctive Cambrian fauna with a Paleozoic fauna, rich in suspension feeders and pelagic animals. It happened just after the Cambrian-Ordovician extinction, which was probably caused by a sudden glaciation and the depletion of the available oxygen in the sea.\nThe main cause of the Ordovician radiation was a major change in paleogeography. Because of the high sea levels, continents became very provincial. Orogeny (together with erosion) became very intense and caused high productivity of the ecosystems during that time, because of the increase in available nutrients.\nThe Cambrian Explosion was important, because it created most of the modern phyla, but the GOBE can be considered as the filling out of the phyla with the modern classes and lower-level taxa.

Life during the Ordovician continued to flourish; however, a mass extinction happened at the boundary with Silurian, which wiped out as many as 85% of marine animal species. On the whole, the fauna that emerged in the Ordovician was the template for the remainder of the Palaeozoic.

The Silurian is a relatively short geological period, lasting about 25 million years.\nLaurentia collided with Baltica, closing the northern branch of the Iapetus Ocean and forming the \"Old Red Sandstone\" continent. Coral reefs expanded, and land plants began to colonize the barren continents.

The evolutionary appearance of vascular plants dramatically altered Earth’s environment, because it paved the way for animal life on land and irrevocably changed Earth’s atmosphere. Puzzlingly, plant evolution was much faster than animal evolution: in the Late Silurian, plants were structurally very simple and small, but by the end of the Devonian (approximately 46 million years later), almost all the present-day plant lineages (except flowering plants) were present.
The answer to this may be that conquering the land presented a bigger challenge for plants than for animals. At the level of the individual organism, all plants (except parasitic ones) must perform four very basic functions to grow and survive:
1. Intercept sunlight.
2. Exchange atmospheric gases with the environment.
3. Acquire, transport, and conserve water.
4. Cope with external mechanical forces.
Each of these tasks makes the others more difficult. For example: a) when a plant increases its surface area to intercept more sunlight and increase the exchange of gases, its ability to conserve water decreases; b) when a plant positions its leaves horizontally to optimize light interception, it increases mechanical stresses.
Aquatic environments are fairly similar and relatively stable, but terrestrial ones are heavily affected by wind, temperature fluctuations, erratic precipitation, and variations in sunlight. Adapting to life in various land environments therefore requires different answers for each of the tasks mentioned above, which prompted a great diversification in plant body forms.
Greater exposure to UV light (and resulting mutations) above the surface of the ocean certainly also played a part, but the plant fitness theory best explains the rapid evolution of land plants.

Multi-cellular life began to appear on land in the form of small, bryophyte-like and vascular plants that grew beside lakes, streams, and coastlines. Arthropods are also first found on land during the Silurian; however, terrestrial life would not greatly diversify and affect the landscape until the Devonian.\nA significant evolutionary milestone during this period was the diversification of the bony fishes.

The Devonian is the fourth of the six periods of the Paleozoic era. It was a relatively warm period, periodically disrupted by glaciations. The weather was very arid, particularly along the equator. By the Devonian, the Early Paleozoic oceans were closing, forming a “pre-Pangea”. Fish were able to migrate from the southern hemisphere continents to North America and Europe. Forests grew for the first time in the equatorial regions of what is now Artic Canada. It ended with a major extinction which wiped out half of all genera.

The Late Devonian extinction was one of five major extinction events in the history of the Earth. It is not a single event, but sequence of two called Kellwaser and Hangenberg events. It is thought that around 75% of all animal species disappeared. It primarily affected marine life – devastating groups like brachiopods, trilobites and reef-building organisms, which almost completely collapsed. Major fish groups like Placodermi, Heterostraci, and Anaspida were wiped out completely. It destroyed 97% of all vertebrate species, with only smaller forms surviving. After the event, no sharks greater than a meter and almost no fishes and tetrapods greater than 10 centimeters remained, and it would take 10 million years before they started to increase in size again. However, the Late Devonian extinction crucially cleared the way for modern vertebrate fauna, including actinopterygians, chondrichthyans, and tetrapods.
The Late Devonian crash in biodiversity was more drastic than the famous extinction event at the end of the Cretaceous.
The causes of this extinction are unclear. However, some possibilities are:
1. Asteroid impact.
2. Changes in plants (especially of their root system), which caused massive water eutrophication and subsequent anoxia.
3. Reduction in atmospheric carbon dioxide, which caused global cooling.
4. Magmatism and increased volcanic activity.

Free-sporing vascular plants began to spread across dry land, covering the continents with extensive forests. By the Middle Devonian, several groups of plants had evolved leaves and true roots. Groups like lycophytes, equisetophytes and pteridophytes diversified.\nFish achieved substantial diversity during this time, giving the Devonian the moniker “Age of Fish”. Placodermi were the most dominant. The ancestors of tetrapods began adapting to walk on land, as their strong pectoral and pelvic fins gradually evolved into legs.\nThe first ammonites (a group of molluscs) appeared, and trilobites and the great coral reefs were still common. A now-dry barrier reef, located in what is now the Kimberley Basin of Northwest Australia, once extended a thousand kilometers.

The name Carboniferous means “coal-bearing” and it is the period when all the major coal deposits formed. During the Early Carboniferous the Paleozoic oceans between Euramerica and Gondwana began to close, forming the Appalachian and Variscan mountains. An ice cap grew at the South Pole, and four-legged vertebrates evolved in the coal swamps near the Equator.

The Carboniferous Rainforest Collapse was a minor extinction event that occurred around 305 million years ago. It altered the vast coal forests that covered the equatorial region, fragmenting them into isolated islands, which in turn caused dwarfism and, shortly after, extinction of many plant and animal species.
This event caused the extinction of the dominant lycopsids and a change to the tree-fern-dominated ecosystems, which were more opportunistic. Before the collapse, the distribution of animal species was very cosmopolitan, but after the collapse each surviving rainforest “island” developed its own unique mix of species; in other words, it caused endemism.
Oxygen levels peaked in the Carboniferous at a record-breaking 32.5%, supporting the enormous arthropods of the time. However, after the Carboniferous Rainforest Collapse, oxygen levels declined, and the giant arthropods like Meganeura and Arthropleura were wiped out. Many amphibian species became extinct, as the climate became more arid, creating the opportunity for the diversification of reptiles, which were physiologically better adapted to arid conditions.
There are several hypotheses about the nature and cause of this event, but the most widely accepted are the aridification of the climate, and volcanism.
This event also contributed to the formation of the large coal deposits. During the Carboniferous, continents were covered by vast swamps, which inhibited the decomposition of dead trees. Additionally, animals and decomposing bacteria had not yet evolved enzymes to effectively digest the resistant phenolic lignin and waxy suberin polymers. Fungi that could break down those substances arose towards the end of the period, making subsequent coal formation much rarer.

The Carboniferous is famous for its vast rainforests of Lepidodendron, Sigillaria, and Calamites, which were the biggest rainforests in Earth’s history. Giant arthropods and insects appeared due to the high atmospheric oxygen levels and lack of predators. Terrestrial vertebrates became more abundant – amphibians became very diverse, and after the Carboniferous collapse reptiles started to prosper.

The Permian is the last period of the Paleozoic era. It ended with the largest mass extinction in Earth’s history. The world at the time was dominated by two continents known as Pangaea and Siberia, surrounded by a global ocean called Panthalassa. Vast deserts covered Western Pangea during the Permian, as reptiles spread across the face of the supercontinent.

The Permian – and the entire Paleozoic Era – ended 252 million years ago with the most severe mass extinction in Earth’s history. The Permian-Triassic extinction event, also known as the Great Dying, killed off 95% of all marine and 70% of all terrestrial species.
It affected marine environments badly: such marine groups like acanthodes, sea scorpions, trilobites (which had long been in decline), fusulinids, Tabulata and Rugosa corals were totally wiped out. It severely affected shelly marine animals, especially molluscs; it wiped out 96% of brachiopods, 97% of ammonites, 59% of bivalves, and 98% of gastropods.
Terrestrial life was also profoundly affected, wiping out most large tetrapod species and 80% of insects. Paleozoic wet forests containing Sigillaria, Lepidodendron, Gigantopteris plants were devastated because of the arid climate and global fires.
There were several causes of this event:
1. Hyperactive volcanism in the area now known as the Siberian traps. Volcanoes freed massive amounts of methane and hydrogen-sulfides into atmosphere, severely altering atmospheric chemistry. Methane reacts with oxygen, so atmospheric oxygen plummeted from 30% to just 13%. The gases also badly damaged the ozone layer; the resulting surge in UV radiation damaged terrestrial habitats. Finally, the surge in methane and other greenhouse gases resulted in a much hotter climate - Earth’s temperature mean rose by an incredible 8 degrees Celsius. 
2. The oceans suffered from massive deoxygenation – there was far less atmospheric oxygen to absorb, and the increase in temperature decreased absorption rates. The increased atmospheric sulfide caused a spike in ocean acidity. Acid disintegrates the carbonate shells of molluscs and corals, which is why so many of them died out. A surge in cyanobacteria and microbialites consumed much of the little oxygen that remained. In other words, oceans became vast, acidic, anoxic deserts, hostile to almost all existing marine life. 
3. Weakness in the Earth’s magnetic field caused an increase in solar radiation, so the extreme heat was repeatedly replace by exceptionally cold winters.
This event was so devastating, that Earth’s ecosystems did not recover their former diversity for 30 million years – not until the Middle Triassic. It selectively destroyed dominating Paleozoic organisms by wiping out 79% of their families and only 27% of the ones which will later thrive during the Mesozoic.

The Permian began with the Carboniferous flora still flourishing. In the Middle Permian a major transition in vegetation began. The swamp-loving lycopod trees, such as Lepidodendron and Sigillaria were progressively replaced by the more advanced seed ferns (like Glossopteris) and early conifers, gingkoes, and cycads.\nThe most successful insects were primitive relatives of cockroaches and early dragonflies. Early Permian terrestrial faunas were dominated by pelycosaurs and amphibians. By the Middle Permian these gave way to primitive therapsids. And in the Late Permian these were in turn replaced by more advanced therapsids, such as gorgonopsians. Towards the very end of the Permian, the first archosaurs appeared – a group that would give rise to the dinosaurs after the Great Dying. Also appearing at the end of the Permian were the first cynodonts, which would go on to evolve into mammals during the Triassic.

The Triassic began in the wake of Permian-Triassic extinction event, which left the Earth’s biosphere impoverished. Life did not recover until the middle of this period.\nThe supercontinent of Pangea, mostly assembled by the Triassic, allowed land animals to migrate from the South Pole to the North Pole, and warm-water faunas spread across the Tethys Sea.

The nocturnal bottleneck hypothesis explains several mammal traits. This hypothesis states that mammals were mainly – or even exclusively – nocturnal through most of their evolutionary story, starting their origin 225 million years ago, and only ending with the demise of the dinosaurs 65 million years ago. While some mammal groups have later evolved to fill diurnal niches, the 160 million years spent as nocturnal animals has left a lasting legacy on basal anatomy and physiology, and most mammals are still nocturnal.
Mammals evolved from cynodonts, a group of superficially dog-like reptiles, in the wake of the Permian-Triassic mass extinction. The emerging archosaurian groups that flourished after the extinction, including crocodiles and dinosaurs, drove the larger cynodonts into extinction, leaving only smaller forms. The surviving cynodonts could only succeed in niches with minimal competition from the diurnal dinosaurs, evolving into the typical small-bodied insectivorous dwellers of the nocturnal undergrowth.
Despite the massive extinction at the end of the Cretaceous, mammals continued to be small-bodied for millions of years. While all the largest animals alive today are mammals, the majority of mammals are still small and nocturnal.
This hypothesis also explains why mammals became warm blooded, because at night temperatures are cooler, and their early burrowing lifestyle required more thermo-isolation.

The Permian-Triassic extinction devastated both terrestrial and marine life. Biodiversity rebounded in the Triassic, as the surviving species repopulated empty terrain, but these were short lived. At first, 90% of the big terrestrial vertebrates belonged to a single genus of therapsids – Lystrosaurus – a sure sign that ecosystems were badly damaged as biodiversity was low. Diverse communities with complex food-web structures took another 30 million years to re-establish themselves. By the Middle Triassic, big therapsids were replaced by archosaurs (the ancestors of dinosaurs, crocodiles, and birds), and the dinosaurs began to establish themselves.\nSeed plants began to displace spores to dominate the terrestrial flora: in the northern hemisphere conifers, ferns, and bennettitales; and in the southern hemisphere Glossopteris trees.\nAs with other periods, this period ended with a mass extinction, which wiped out conodonts, most of the marine reptiles and invertebrates, and some remaining large therapsids and amphibians.

The Jurassic is the second period of the Mesozoic era, also known as the Age of Reptiles. The supercontinent of Pangea began to break apart in the Middle Jurassic. In the Late Jurassic the Central Atlantic Ocean was a narrow ocean separating Africa from North America. Eastern Gondwana had begun to separate from Western Gondwana.

About 20 million years after the Permian-Triassic extinction, dinosaurs diverged from their archosaurian ancestors and began to challenge the reigning archosauromorphs and therapsids. At first, they were not the dominant terrestrial animals, but after the Triassic-Jurassic extinction, which wiped out many of their competitors, they rose to prominence and occupied all the main niches for the next 135 million years.
Two main questions now are:
1. How did some of the terrestrial dinosaurs become so massive? Most of the sauropods were huge – Argentinosaurus (weighing more than 100 tons), Mamenchisaurus, Diplodocus etc.
2. Were dinosaurs feathered and warm blooded, or not?
Both of these questions are closely related, however there are still no clear answers.
The largest dinosaurs were herbivores, and a larger body is better protection against predators. In a crowded ecological space, herbivores may have evolved towards the only available unfilled niches – larger size – causing a “race to the top”, within the limits imposed by the physical environment and ecological capacity.
The largest sauropods grew incredibly fast – up to 5000 kg per year. Such growth rates require a very high metabolism, which is not usually observed in cold-blooded animals. However, a high metabolism (and warm blood) can become a disadvantage as body mass increases, as it requires more energy to heat – and to cool - larger volumes. Scientists now think that growing sauropods probably were warm-blooded, but their metabolism probably decreased as they approached their adult size.
We still have much to learn about dinosaurian physiology, but the traditional presentation of dinosaurs as cold blooded, lizard-like reptiles is giving way to a sense that most dinosaurs probably had some kind of thermoregulation. Recent dinosaur discoveries in North America provide evidence of at least seasonal dinosaurian presence in colder environments. And the latest discoveries of feathered velociraptors show that even large dinosaurs were feathered – likely even the notorious Tyrannosaurus Rex. The only dinosaurs that survived the Cretaceous-Paleogene extinction – today’s birds – are feathered and warm blooded, so why not the larger Jurassic dinosaurs?

During the Jurassic period, the dominant marine vertebrates were fish and marine reptiles like ichthyosaurs (marine reptiles that resembled today’s dolphins), plesiosaurs (long-necked marine reptiles), pliosaurs (a version of the plesiosaur with a shorter neck and longer head), and crocodiles. Numerous turtles could be found in lakes and rivers.\nThe Jurassic was a golden age for the sauropods (large, long-necked herbivores like Diplodocus). During the Late Jurassic, the first avialans (bird-like dinosaurs), like Archaeopteryx, evolved.\nThe arid, continental conditions characteristic of the Triassic steadily eased during the Jurassic period. The warm, humid climate allowed lush jungles to cover much of the landscape. The conifers in particular dominated the flora.

The Cretaceous is the last period of the Mesozoic era, ending with a large mass extinction – the famous comet that destroyed the dinosaurs. It was a period with a relatively warm climate, resulting in high sea levels that created numerous shallow inland seas.\nDuring the Cretaceous the South Atlantic Ocean opened. India separated from Madagascar and raced northward on a collision course with Eurasia. Notice that North America was connected to Europe, and that Australia was still joined to Antarctica.
End of the Age of Dinosaurs

The Cretaceous period ended with a massive extinction event, known as Cretaceous-Paleogene extinction. Numerous plant and animal species on Earth were wiped out, and all the non-avian dinosaurs became dead. With the exception of some cold-blooded species like turtles and crocodiles, no tetrapods weighing more than 25 kilograms survived. It marked the end of the Cretaceous period and with it, the entire Mesozoic Era, opening the Cenozoic Era that continues today.
What could cause such a massive extinction? Now there are almost no disputes, that the cause of this event was a massive asteroid – 10-15 kilometers in diameter – falling near what is now Mexico’s Yucatan Peninsula. The consequences of this impact were of a planet-wide cataclysm. Dust blocked the sun for an entire year, preventing photosynthesis. Plant species died out, followed by the herbivores that fed on them and the carnivores that fed on the herbivores. The asteroid also happened to strike a region of sulfur-rich carbonate rock, which caused higher ocean acidity. As in the Great Dying, which ended the Paleozoic, the sharp increase in acidity wiped out many shelly marine animals, especially molluscs (like ammonites) and corals, and the animals that depended on them for food. The sea surface temperature dropped as much as 7 degrees Celsius for decades after the impact. It would take several hundred thousand years for Earth’s geochemistry to recover.
The sustained disruption killed all the reigning non-avian dinosaurs. One interesting question is why the catastrophe did not wipe out the dinosaurs’ close relatives, the crocodilians. It is thought, that cold-blooded crocodiles have a much more limited need for food (they can survive months without eating) while warm-blooded animals of similar size need far more food (still more evidence that dinosaurs were likely warm-blooded, at least to some extent).
The elimination of the dominant Cretaceous groups allowed other organisms to take their place, spurring a remarkable series of adaptive radiations in Paleogene. The most striking example is the replacement of dinosaurs by mammals, who quickly diversified to fill the places left by the dinosaurs. In an important sense, therefore, the ultimate evolution of humans depended critically upon the extinction of the dinosaurs.

Flowering plants (angiosperms) appeared for the first time during the Cretaceous, however they did not become dominant until close to the end of the period. Their evolution was aided by the appearance of bees. In fact, angiosperms and insects are good examples of coevolution. The first representatives of many leafy trees, including figs, planes, and magnolias appeared in the Cretaceous.
On land, mammals were generally small in size, but an important component of the fauna. The apex predators were of course the archosaurian reptiles, especially dinosaurs, which were at their most diverse stage. Pterosaurs were common in the Early and Middle Cretaceous, but as the period proceeded, they declined (for reasons that are still poorly understood).
Insects diversified during Cretaceous, with the appearance of ants, termites, butterflies and moths, aphids, grasshoppers, and gall wasps.
In the seas - rays, modern sharks, and bony fish became common. Marine reptiles included ichthyosaurs in the Early and Middle Cretaceous, with plesiosaurs and mosasaurs appearing before the end of the period.

The Paleogene is the first period of the Cenozoic Era. This period consists of Paleocene, Eocene, and Oligocene epochs. The end of the Paleocene (about 55 million years ago) was marked by the Eocene Thermal Maximum, one of the most important periods of global change during the Cenozoic. The global climate during the Paleogene began a cooling and drying trend, periodically disrupted by warm periods. The trend was caused partially by the formation of the Antarctic Circumpolar Current, which significantly lowered oceanic water temperatures.\nDuring this time, India began to collide with Asia forming the Tibetan plateau and the Himalaya Mountains. Australia, which had been attached to Antarctica, began to move rapidly northward.

The Eocene thermal maximum was a time period with 5-8 °C warmer global average temperature than today. This climate event began at the time boundary between the Paleocene and Eocene geological epochs around 55.5 million years ago.
It was propelled by two massive carbon injections, each lasting 1,500 years. The entire warm period lasted for about 200,000 years. The amount of carbon released during this time was more than 30 times larger than all the fossil fuels burned to date and equivalent to all the current fossil fuel reserves we have.
This event was probably caused by melting of seafloor methane ices (clathrates), or volcanism heating organic-rich rocks and releasing methane.
There was enhanced storminess in some areas (allusion to the modern storm regions of Caribbean and East Asia), increased aridity in tropical region and increased humidity closer to the poles. While there was significant ecological disruption, most species (except deep-sea foraminifera) were able to avoid extinction via adaptation or migration. First wave of modern mammals showed up, including ancestral primates, ungulates and cetaceans. Continent-scale migration of animals, and plants, ranges were shifted. Increased temperatures caused decrease in body size in mammalian species (dwarfism). There is a proposition, that under elevated carbon dioxide levels plants grow quickly, but are less nutritious than they normally would be. It might describe, why early horses experienced a body-size decrease of about 20-30%.
The rate at which carbon emissions warmed Earth’s climate resembles modern, human-caused global warming and can provide clues to the future of modern climate change.

Mammals began a rapid diversification during this period; some mammals evolved into large forms that would dominate on land, while others would adapt to marine life. Those that took to the oceans became modern cetaceans, while those that took to the trees became primates. Birds, which were already well established by the end of the Cretaceous, also experienced an adaptive radiation, as they took over skies free of the now-extinct pterosaurs. As the climate cooled, tropical plants became less numerous, and their range was restricted to equatorial regions.

The Neogene is a period that spans 20.45 million years. It is sub-divided into two epochs, the earlier Miocene and the later Pliocene. The Isthmus of Panama connected North and South America later in the Pliocene, cutting off the Atlantic Ocean from the warm ocean currents from the Pacific, and leaving only the Gulf Stream to transfer heat to the Arctic Ocean. The global climate cooled considerably over the course of the Neogene, culminating in a series of continental glaciations in the Quaternary period that follows.\n20 million years ago, Antarctica was covered by ice and the northern continents were cooling rapidly. The world has taken on a \"modern\" look, but notice that Florida and parts of Asia were under water.

During the Neogene world became much drier and cooler, culminating disaster of the Pleistocene ice ages and the harsh conditions of our own day. During this interval, the relatively uniform and stable climatic regime which had cradled the world’s ecosystems for 200 million years, since the Late Triassic, came to a comparatively quick end. The drift of the continents had sealed off the waters of the far arctic, as the northern margins of Asia and North America crowded together. The closing of the Isthmus of Panama prevented warm currents from the Pacific to the Atlantic. In the south, Antarctica, now out of contact with any other landmass, was circled by a continuous circum-polar current. Perhaps for the first time since the Ordovician, both poles were thermally isolated from the warm equatorial waters and started accumulating heavy coverings of ice. The ice sheets, in turn reflected more sunlight and lowered sea levels, further reducing temperatures and warm-water circulation.\nThe world dried out, huge deserts developed in North Africa and Central Asia. The deep forests of the continental interiors were replaced by arid plains, steppe, prairie or tundra. Many herbivorous animal species died out or were forced to change together with their predators. By the end of the period, the world became similar to what we see now.

During this period, mammals and birds continued to evolve into roughly modern forms, while other groups remained relatively unchanged. Early hominids, the ancestors of humans, appeared in Africa near the end of this period and later spread into Eurasia. Tropical plant species gave way to deciduous ones and grasslands replaced many forests. Grasses therefore greatly diversified, and herbivorous mammals evolved alongside it, creating the many grazing animals of today, such as horses and antelopes.

The Quaternary Period is the current and most recent of the three periods of the Cenozoic Era. It is divided into two epochs: the Pleistocene and the Holocene (which began 11,700 years ago). The Quaternary is typically defined by the cyclic growth and decay of continental ice sheets driven by Milankovitch cycles and the associated climate and environmental changes that occurred. The last expansion of the polar ice sheets took place about 12,000 years ago.

The Quaternary is a period of the repeating glaciations, which are defined by the previously mentioned Milankovitch cycles. The angle of Earth’s axial tilt with respect to the orbital plane varies between 22.1 and 24.5 degrees over a cycle of about 41,000 years. The current tilt is 23.44 degrees, roughly halfway between its extreme values. Increased tilt increases the amplitude of the seasonal cycle, providing more solar radiation in each hemisphere’s summer and less in winter – in other words, climate at higher latitudes becomes warmer and stops glaciation. The tilt last reached its maximum 10,700 years ago and now is in the decreasing phase of its cycle and will reach its minimum in 9,800 years. The current trend of decreasing tilt will promote milder seasons, as well as an overall cooling trend. A new Ice Age is approaching.\nIn order to understand the impact of the glaciations, we should compare three regions at roughly the same latitude – China, North America, and Europe. Chinese flora is extremely rich, with million-year-old relics like Ginkgo, Magnolia, and Thujopsis. North America, too, has such ancient plants as Taxodium and Sequoiadendron. Europe, however, has essentially no ancient plant groups at all (except for a few in the Mediterranean). Why is it that the Ice Ages affected plants in China and North America so differently from those in Europe? The answer lies in geography. Glaciations affect European plant life more severely: during the last glaciation, most of Europe was buried under ice and it was very difficult for Europe’s plants to escape southwards, because they were blocked by the Alps and Mediterranean Sea, both of which extend generally from east to west. (The Mediterranean region was able to retain some ancient plants like Platanus and Olea). North America, especially it’s eastern coastal region, was usually free of snow, and its mountains run generally north-south, making it easier for plants to retreat southward, away from the encroaching glaciers. China, in contrast, was not covered by glaciers at all. It’s hard to imagine that before the Quaternary, Europe was home to gingkoes and beautiful Magnolias.\nQuaternary glaciations also obstructed humans from migrating into Europe, and repeatedly destroyed the populations that did settle there.

The Quaternary is the modern period, and it represents our current fauna and flora. However, periodic glaciations had a huge impact on the terrestrial biota, frequently destroying plant and animal species. After the last ice age, many large Pleistocene mammals such as saber-tooth cats, mammoths, and mastodons became extinct worldwide.

It is very hard to predict the future; however, we as an intelligent life forms can try to contemplate it. \nEarth will vanish eventually, because the Sun has its lifetime and will swallow our planet (unless our future siblings will be able to transfer Earth somewhere else). It is thought, that Earth’s habitable-zone lifespan is as long as 7.79 billion years. Because we already spent 4.56 billion years, we got around 3.23 billion years left, or even less – 1.75 billion years due to some scientists. It will get progressively hotter and there is nothing we can do about it. Sun converts hydrogen into helium and when the significant portion of it will be converted – it will undergo an internal change and become a Red Giant. This is how it is.\nBut it is an ideal case.

Life already showed it’s persistence and will to exist, so it will flourish with humans or without them. The current trends and risen concern in society about the ecology bring some optimism, because about 20 years ago people still believed EXXON lying about the non existent climate change and no one was thinking about the pollution etc. However, changes will occur anyway despite our wishes.
There is a hidden bomb in our understanding of the economy. Usually if country shows an economic growth of below the 3% it is portrayed as a slow growing one. But what does it mean to grow 3% per year? It basically means, that every 20 years economy doubles and current economy trends show, that with economic growth, energy consumption grows too. Since the industrial revolution we increased our energy consumption rates dramatically and we still use carbon-rich fossil fuel everywhere. Renewable energy still occupies just a tiny part of our produced energy.
The main law in physics states, that energy always emits heat – by the current calculations in 400 years we will need as much energy as the Sun provides and we will basically boil our oceans, if energy will be used as inefficiently as it is used today. And in 2000 years we will need energy of all the Milky Way galaxy stars. Now imagine Milky Way and its minimum diameter of 100,000 light years and ask yourself – is it possible to retain such consumption tempo?
It is more likely, that humanity will discover way more efficient energy sources and will adapt to live on Earth, because now humanity is trying to adapt Earth for life with people.
At the moment something similar to the Permian-Triassic extinction is happening now, but in faster rates. We dump tons of the carbon dioxide, Earth started to heat and already melts its polar caps, which contain massive amounts of trapped methane inside. Oceanic acidity had already risen during the recent years and it caused the partial death of the worldwide coral reefs, and anoxia is already spreading. Forests, which should fixate all the carbon dioxide are being cut for economic purposes. The sea levels will continue to rise. Such places like Florida, East Asia already suffer from the mass floods.
Current events are driving Earth’s life towards the next mass extinction, however at least now it gather much more publicity and required attention.
Life will always flourish. Even in the radioactive bogs full of acid.

Banded iron formations are distinctive units of sedimentary rock. Typical unit consists of repeated thin layers of silver to black iron oxides, alternating with other iron-poor bands - red hematites.\nThe main hypothesis is that banded iron layers were formed in sea water as the result of oxygen released by photosynthetic cyanobacteria, that\'s why their occurrence in the Early Archean might show existence of life as early as 3.85 billion years ago.\nIt is assumed that initially Earth had vast amounts of iron dissolved in the world\'s seas. As photosynthetic organisms generated oxygen, the available iron precipitated as iron oxides and it contributed to these geological bodies.

Stromatolites are layered, accretionary structures formed in the shallow water by trapping, binding and cementation of sedimentary grains by microbial mats of microorganisms, especially cyanobacteria.\nFossilized stromatolites provide ancient records of life on Earth. They exhibit a variety of forms and structures. Although stromatolites are usually associated with biological activity, some possess features that are more consistent with abiotic precipitation.\nPeak of their diversity was reached about 1.25 billion years ago and subsequently declined in abundance and diversity later. Modern stromatolites are rare and are mostly found in hypersaline lakes or marine lagoons where extreme conditions due to high saline levels prevent animal grazing.

Primaevifilum amoenum is the oldest known bacteria, which remains were found in Western Australia. It was a filamentous microorganism, which preferred living in individual clasts, although possibly representing a benthic microbial community that was loosely organised and embedded in mucilage. Their microfossils have not been detected in stromatolite-like laminated clasts.

Acritarchs are any small, unclassified, non-acid soluble organic structures. They include the remains of a wide range and different kinds of organisms – ranging from the egg cases of small animals to resting cysts of many different kinds of green algae.

Bangiomorpha is the first known sexually reproducing organism. It belongs to red algae (Rhodophyta). Sex was critical for the subsequent success of eukaryotes (we are eukaryotes too), not so much for the advantages of genetic recombination, but because it allowed for complex multicellularity. This is the reason, why this organism is important.

Nemiana simplex is one of the simplest, sessile animals of all Ediacarans, similar to a jellyfish. It consists of a jelly-like sac filled with its various internal structures. Probably it also had small tentacles.\nIt is possible, that this creature did not move and fed upon the algae.

Tribrachidium is a tri-radially symmetrical creature that lived in the Late Proterozoic. It was as soft-bodied benthic organism that was temporarily attached to the substrate of its habitat. It probably fed on organic particles dissolved in the ancient oceans.

Dickinsonia is one of the first organisms resembling bilateral symmetry which prevails in the majority of the modern animals. Their growth was probably indeterminate, because found specimen range from a few millimetres to about 1.4 metres in length. They kept growing until they were covered by the ocean sediments and/or killed. Dickinsonia spent most, if not all, of its life with most of the body firmly anchored to the sediment.

Cloudinids are among the earliest animals with mineralized skeletons. They formed millimetre-scale conical fossils consisting of calcareous cones nested within one another. Mineralized skeleton might be a proof of the evolution of more complex animal relationships by the end of the Proterozoic. Until then, most of the organisms were benthic filtrators, but the end of Proterozoic evidences appearance of the predators.

Charnia is a highly significant fossil, because it is the first fossil that was ever described from undoubted Precambrian rocks. Also it is thought, that it is a first animal which reproduced sexually. Although it looks like a fern – Charnia is not a plant or algae because it originally lived in a deep water, well below a photic zone where photosynthesis can occur. It is believed to have fed on nutrients dissolved in the water.

Treptichnus pedum is a crucial fossil, because it is the first discovered burrowing creature which actually helped to define the dividing line between Ediacaran and Cambrian periods.\nSince only its burrows have been found, it is presumed that the Treptichnus animal lacked any anatomical features such as shells or bones. Probably they are related with modern priapulids.

Conodonta are ancient agnathan chordates resembling eels. Conodonts are very important, because their fossils are used to separate geological periods (index fossils). They ranged from 1 to 40 cm in length and had big and sharp teeth. Although their teeth look scary, conodonts probably were not active predators because of the lateral position of their eyes.

Archaeocyatha are first big skeletal animals and primary (also first) Cambrian reef builders living in warm tropical and subropical waters. Some of the archaeocyaths were solitary organisms, while others formed colonies.\nThey resembled a hollow horn coral and their skeleton was made from calcite.\nAround 516 mya, they went into a sharp decline which coincided with a rapid diversification of the demosponges.

Trilobites form one of the earliest known groups of arthropods and are classic examples of the Cambrian fauna which flourished throughout Paleozoic era. Their diversity greatly declined during the Devonian and group became extinct by the end of the Permian. The trilobites were among the most successful of all early animals, roaming the oceans for over 270 million years.\nThey had many lifestyles – some moved over the sea as predators, scavengers, or filter feeders, and some swam feeding on plankton.\nIf you will ever consider traveling to Morocco, you will likely see lots of merchants selling cheap trilobite fossils, because Anti-Atlas mountains are made of Paleozoic rocks.

Wiwaxia is a genus of soft-bodied animals that were covered in carbonaceous scales and spines. The long dorsal spines may have been a defence against predators, it apparently moved by contractions of a slug like foot on its underside.
Myllokunmingia is a genus of basal chordate, which is 28 mm long and 6 mm high. It is among the oldest possible craniates and appears to have a skull and skeletal structures made of cartilage.

Pikaia is one of the oldest known vertebrate ancestors, which had a worm-like appearance and perhaps swam much like an eel. Fossils show chordate features such as traces of an elongate notochord, dorsal nerve chord and myotomes – all critical features for the evolution of the vertebrates.

Anomalocaris is an animal which is thought to be closely related to ancestral arthropods. It was one of the largest animals and predators in the Cambrian oceans, and could grow up to a metre in length. It had sophisticated stalked eyes with at least 16000 lenses each. These compound eyes were as acute as the best of modern insects. It also had a mouth with square ring of sharp teeth.

Opabinia was a soft-bodied animal of a modest size (4–7 cm in length). Its segmented body had lobes along the sides and a fan-shaped tail. The head shows unusual features: five eyes, a mouth under the head facing backwards, and a proboscis that probably passed food to the mouth.\nIt probably lived on the seafloor, using the proboscis to seek out small and soft food.

Marrella is an arthropod known from the Middle Cambrian. It was a small animal, 2 cm or less in length which scavenged detrite along the bottom of the sea. It is currently accepted that Marrella is a stem group arthropod - in other words, it descended from an ancestor common to it and most or all of the later major arthropod groups. Despite its superficial similarity to the trilobites, it is no more closely related to this group than it is to any other arthropod.

Foraminifera are members of ameboid protists characterized by streaming granular ectoplasm that among other things are used for catching food, and commonly by an external shell made of various materials and constructed in diverse forms. Most of them are marine and very few are known from freshwater. Their shells are made of calcium carbonate and are usually less than 1 mm in size, but some reach up to 20 cm. Foraminifera are also used as index fossils for the Permian, Jurassic, Cretaceous and Cenozoic.

Hallucigenia is considered to represent an early ancestor of the living velvet worms, although other researchers favour a relationship closer to arthropods. Its quirky name reflects its unusual appearance and eccentric history of study. It was a 0.5-3.5 cm long tubular organism with seven or eight pairs of slender legs, each terminating with a pair of claws.

Orthoceras is a genus of extinct nautiloid cephalopods containing animals with slender and elongate shells. All the living relatives of these nautiloids, squid, octopus, cuttlefish, and nautilus are predators, and we can assume that orthoceras was also a hunter of the Paleozoic seas, possibly having trilobites for breakfast!

Pentecopterus decorahensis is the oldest known sea scorpion at an estimated length up to 1.83 metres. It is also one of the largest arthropods ever discovered.\nSea scorpions were powerful sea predators, roaming the ancient oceans until the Permian great extinction event. They are close relatives of horse-shoe crabs – ancient arthropod group which is still alive.

Sacabambaspis is a jawless fish which is also one of the oldest animals having vertebrate-like skeletal tissues. It had a head shield and the early sensory structure (lateral line) which is present in modern fish.
Astraspis is the oldest known armored jawless fish. Its body was covered with protective bony plates and it had a mobile tail covered with small protective plate-like scales.

Rugosa is an extinct order of solitary and colonial corals that were abundant in Middle Ordovician to Late Permian seas. Solitary individuals are often referred to as horn corals, because of their horn-like shape. Their skeleton was made of calcite and they died during the Permian Great Dying event.

Tabulata is an extinct order of corals, which existed together with Rugosa and died during the same extinction event. They looked like a honeycomb and their skeletons were made from calcite. This is a classic coral of the Paleozoic seas.

Eurypterus is an exctinct genus of sea scorpions, and its fossils are the most common among the group. They were equally likely to engage in predation or scavenging and could grow up to 1.3 m in length. They were capable of breathing air and walking on land for a short amount of time.

Pneumodesmus is the first myriapod and the oldest known creature to have lived on land. It is also the earliest documented arthropod with a tracheal system, and indeed the first known oxygen-breathing animal on land.

Cooksonia is an extinct group of primitive land plants. They include the oldest known plant to have a stem with vascular tissue. They lacked leaves, blossoms and roots, they were also small, a few centimetres tall. Each branch ended in a sporangium or spore-bearing capsule.
Baragwanathia is a genus of extinct Lycopodiophyta plants. They had unbranched strap-shaped microphylls and vascular bundle in the stems was an actinostelle.

Acanthodians (sometimes called spiny sharks) are fish which share features both with bony and cartilaginous fish. They represent several independent phylogenetic branches of fish leading to the still living Chondrichthyes (sharks and chimaeras). They also represent early jawed fish.
Entelognathus represents the earliest placoderms. It also is the first fish with dermal marginal jaw bones (premaxillare, maxillare and dentale).

Prototaxites is a genus of fungus, which formed large trunk-like structures up to 1 metre wide, reaching 8 metres in height. Although appearing in the Late Silurian, it reached its greatest diversity by the Devonian. Recent discovery of what are likely algal symbionts makes it a lichen, rather than a fungus in the strict sense.\nIt became extinct when the shrubs and vascular trees rose to prominence.

Wattieza is a genus of the prehistoric tree (also the oldest one), that existed in the Middle Devonian and were close relatives of the modern ferns and horsetails. They could grow up to 8 m or more, furthermore they reproduced with spores.

Archaeopteris is an extinct genus of tree-like plants with fern-like leaves, it could grow up to 10 metres in height and had trunks which exceeded 1.5 metres in diameter. It preferred wet soils, growing close to river systems and in flood plain woodlands. It is also a distant ancestor of the gymnosperm plants (like conifers).

Although it looks like amphibian, Tiktaalik is a lobe-finned fish from the Late Devonian, having many features akin to those of tetrapods. Tiktaalik has a possibility of being a representative of the evolutionary transition from fish to amphibians. It is an example of the several lines of ancient sarcopterygian fish developing adaptations to the oxygen-poor shallow-water habitats – environmental conditions which are thought to have led to the evolution of tetrapods.\nIt is thought, that this animal was specialized for living in swampy, pond-like habitats and maybe occasionally it used its very specialized fins to move up overland.

Ichthyostega is one of the first tetrapods in the fossil record that lived at the end of the Devonian. It possessed lungs and limbs that helped it navigate through shallow water in swamps. Although it looks like amphibian, it is still a stem group tetrapod and one of the closest amphibian ancestors. It had fish-like tail and gills, however it also had an amphibian skull and limbs.

Bothriolepis is a widespread, abundant and diverse genus of placoderms, that was present during the Middle to Late Devonian period. Largest species could reach about 1 metre in length. It fed on detritus, algae and small microorganisms.
Cladoselache is one of the earliest known shark groups, which grew up to 1.8 metres long. They were fast and agile predators and had from 5 to 7 gill slits with short, rounded mouth.

Dunkleosteus is an extinct genus of placoderm fish that existed during the Late Devonian. The largest species could grow up to 6 metres in length and weigh up to 1 tonne. It was a hypercarnivorous apex predator.\nDue to its heavily armoured exterior, Dunkleosteus was probably a relatively slow, but powerful swimmer.

Acanthostega is an extinct genus of stem-tetrapod and is among the first vertebrate animals to have recognizable limbs. It was anatomically intermediate form between lobe-finned fishes and those that were fully capable of coming onto land. It could grow up to 60 cm in length and had 8 digits on each hand linked by webbing. Acanthostega probably lived in shallow, weed-choked swamps and it was primarily an aquatic animal.

Materpiscis is a genus of placoderm fish which lived nearby Western Australia. Known from only one specimen, it is unique in having an unborn embryo present inside the mother, with remarkable preservation of a mineralised placental feeding structure. This makes Materpiscis the oldest known vertebrate to show viviparity, or giving birth to live young. It comprises only from the single species, which is called Materpiscis attenboroughi in honour of David Attenborough who first drew attention to significance of the Gogo fish sites in his 1979 series Life on Earth.

Lepidodendron is an extinct tree–like lycopsid. It was a major component of the coal forest flora and sometimes reached over 30 metres in height, and had trunks over 1 m in diameter. It is estimated that these plants grew rapidly and lived 10–15 years. Most of the species were probably monocarpic, meaning that they reproduced only once toward the end of their life. By the Mesozoic era they were probably outcompeted by the emerging woody gymnosperms (ex. conifers).

Sigillaria is an extinct tree-like lycopsid, closely related to Lepidodendron. They could grow up to 30 metres in height and had a relatively short life cycle – growing rapidly and reaching maturity in a few years.
Calamites is and extinct tree-like horsetail. It could grow up to 30 metres tall and was a major component of the Carboniferous coal swamps.

Akmonistion is a shark–like chimaera that lived during the Early Carboniferous. The male had an anvil-shaped crest instead of a dorsal fin. The crest had barbs on top and it also had a triangular patch of spines on top of its head in front of the crest. The female probably looked just like the male, except it might not have had the crest or the triangular patch of spines.

Helicoprion is a long-lived genus of shark–like fish which had spirally arranged clusters of the individuals teeth. They could have grown up to 3–4 m in length with large specimens growing up to 7.5 m.

Pederpes is the earliest known tetrapod to show the beginnings of terrestrial locomotion. It is not considered as an amphibian, but is a very basal (primitive) tetrapod. Pederpes was 1 m long and was well adapted to the terrestrial life. It is currently the earliest known fully terrestrial animal.

Proterogyrinus is a reptile-like amphibian, which probably was one of the reptile ancestors. They could venture further away from the water than most of the amphibians and were top predators both on land and water.

Hylonomus is the earliest unquestionable reptile. It was 20 centimetres long and was similar to the modern lizards. It had small sharp teeth and it likely ate small invertebrates such as millipedes or early insects.

Archaeothyris is the oldest known synapsid – ancestor of the modern mammals. It looked like a modern day lizard, although at 50 centimetres long it was one of the largest carnivores in the Carboniferous forests.

Pulmonoscorpius is a giant species of extinct scorpion, that could grow up to 70 centimetres long. The diet of Pulmonoscorpius is not known directly, but smaller arthropods may have formed part of its diet, and its sting may have been able to kill small tetrapods.

Arthropleura is one of the largest known land invertebrates of all time, which had few, if any, predators. It could grow up to 2.3 metres in length and up to 50 centimetres in width. Arthropleura like other Carboniferous arthropods was able to grow larger due to the greater partial pressure of oxygen in Earth’s atmosphere, and because of the lack of large terrestrial vertebrate predators (that’s why during the Cretaceous there were no such arthropods, although oxygen levels were similar to the Carboniferous).\nIn contrary to the earlier and popular beliefs, Arthropleura was not a predator but a herbivorous arthropod.

Meganeura is an extinct genus of the giant dragonflies, which had a wingspan reaching up to 65 cm in length. Like Arthropleura, they could grow such big due to the greater atmospheric oxygen levels and lack of predators during that time.

Glossopteris is the largest and best-known genus of seed ferns which grew in the Southern Hemisphere during the Permian period. It was a woody, seed-bearing shrub or tree, some apparently reaching 30 meters tall. They have grown in a very wet soil conditions and outcompeted lycopsids such as Sigillaria and Lepidodendron during the Permian.

Dimetrodon is an extinct synapsid, mammal-like reptile. It could reach 4.6 metres in length and could have weighted up to 250 kilograms. It was probably one of the apex predators, feeding on fish and tetrapods. The sail of Dimetrodon may have been used to stabilize its spine and to heat and cool its body as a form of the thermoregulation.

Titanophoneus or in other words – “titanic murderer” is a carnivorous dinocephalian therapsid from the Middle Permian. The adult skull could reach 80 cm, it also had a heavy long snout and its total body length was about 2.9 meters.
Estemmenosuchus (meaning “crowned crocodile” in Greek) was a large omnivorous therapsid. It lived during the Middle Permian and could grow up to 3 meters long.
Gorgonops were the dominant predators of their day and lived during the Late Permian. They could grow up to 3 meters long. They had two enlarged canine teeth, which could grow up to 12 cm in length.

The cynodonts (“dog teeth”) are therapsids that first appeared in the Late Permian. This group includes modern mammals (including humans) as well as their extinct ancestors and close relatives. Non-mammalian cynodonts spread throughout Southern Gondwana and had many mammalian skeletal features. All cynodonts probably laid eggs (like the modern day platypus) and had some form of the warm-blooded metabolism, because many of them had fur.

Bennettitales were plants resembling the flowering plants, because of their flower-like reproductive structures. Although similar, they are more closely related to the modern cycads, ginkgo and conifers than angiosperms. However, this clade is polyphyletic, so there is a possibility, that some Bennettitales form a clade with Angiosperms.

Morganucodon was an early mammaliaform cynodont that lived during the Late Triassic. It was a small nocturnal animal with a body length reaching up to 10 cm – an example specimen of the nocturnal bottleneck effect.

Lystrosaurus was a herbivorous genus of Late Permian and Early Triassic therapsids, which size was similar to the pig. At least one Lystrosaurus specie survived the Permian-Triassic mass extinction and in the absence of predators and herbivorous competitors it became the most common terrestrial vertebrate during the Early Triassic. At one time, almost 90% of the land vertebrates belonged to this genus!

Pterosaurs were flying reptiles, which lived since the Late Triassic until the end of the Cretaceous. They were the earliest vertebrates to have evolved powered flight. Pterosauria were not “flying dinosaurs”, they actually do not belong to the Dinosauria clade.

Plesiosauria was a group of marine reptiles, which lived throughout Mesozoic era. They had a flat body and a short tail. They breathed atmospheric air and bore live young; there are indicators that they were warm-blooded.

Ichthyosaurs were large marine reptiles which thrived during much of the Mesozoic. They were among the top aquatic predators until the Late Jurassic and Cretaceous, when they were outcompeted by the newly emerged plesiosaurs.

Mystriosuchus was a crocodile-like reptile that lived in the Late Triassic. It grew up to 4 metres long, cranial morphology is suggestive of a primarily fish eating diet, having long jaws like those of the modern gharials.

Plateosaurus was a basal sauropodomorph dinosaur (group which will later include some of the largest animals on Earth like Diplodocus, Argentinosaurus etc.). Fully grown individuals were between 5 and 10 metres long and weighted 600–4000 kilograms. Commonly they lived at least from 12 to 20 years.
Desmatosuchus is an extinct genus of archosaurs that could grow up to 4.5 meters in length. They were widespread and it is suggested, that they could have been omnivorous or even insectivorous.
Longisquama is a genus of extinct reptile, which probably has no bearing on the origin of birds. The structures on its back are actually more like scales than feathers.
Sharovipteryx is one of the earliest known gliding reptiles, known only from a single fossil.

Tanystropheus was a 6 metre long reptile with an extremely elongated neck, which measured 3 metres long. Even it looks like a dinosaur, it belongs to another reptile group – protosauria, and is not related to similarly looking sauropods. It was probably aquatic or semi-aquatic and is most often considered to eat fish.

Archaeopteryx is a genus of the bird-like dinosaurs, which shows a transition between the non-avian feathered dinosaurs and the modern birds. Largest individuals possibly were looking like ravens, but in addition they also had jaws with sharp teeth, three clawed fingers on each wing and a long bony tail.

Allosaurus was a large bipedal predator, which could grow up to 8.5 m in length and was at the top of the food chain. Their potential prey included ornithopods, stegosaurids, and sauropods. Some paleontologists interpret Allosaurus as having had cooperative social behavior, and hunting in packs, while others believe individuals may have been aggressive toward each other, and that congregations of this genus are the result of lone individuals feeding on the same carcasses. It may have attacked large prey by ambush, using its upper jaw like a hatchet.

Mamenchisaurus was a sauropod dinosaur genus, which included several species known for their remarkably long necks which made up half of their total body length. The largest species may have reached 35 m in length and possibly weighed 50 to 75 tons.

Stegosaurus is a genus of the armoured dinosaurs. They were large, heavily built herbivorous animals. Their large body plates were probably used for thermoregulatory functions.\nThe first specimen was collected during the “Bone Wars” – famous fossil rivalry between Edward Drinker Cope and Othniel Charles Marsh.
Epidexipteryx was a small bird-like dinosaur, representing the earliest known example of the ornamental feathers in the fossil record.

Dilophosaurus was among the largest predators of its time and had a pair of rounded crests on its skull. It measured about 7 meters long and weighed about 400 kilograms. This dinosaur was inaccurately featured in the Jurassic Park movie - it had no frills, it definitely did not spit poison and was much bigger.

Dimorphodon was a medium-sized pterosaur, which probably inhabited coastal regions. It was a rather poor flyer because of the short wings, and it probably relied on frantic short flights in the same manner as modern fowls and woodpeckers.
Epidendrosaurus was a sparrow-size feathered avialan dinosaur, which probably lived on trees feeding on insects.

Liopleurodon is a genus of large, carnivorous marine reptile belonging to the Plesiosauria group. Their fossils have been found mainly in England and France. Liopleurodon was a powerful swimmer and usually could grow up to 5-7 metres.

Kentrosaurus is a genus of stegosaurian dinosaur from the Late Jurassic of Tanzania. It measured around 4.5 metres in length and weighed about one tonne. Kentrosaurus was a herbivore and probably lived in a predator-heavy environment because of its heavy armouring.

Tyrannosaurus is probably the most famous dinosaur, well known from such TV movies like “Jurassic Park”, “Lost World” etc. Also it is one of the most well-represented large dinosaurs. Tyrannosaurus lived throughout what is now Western North America. The most complete specimen measures up to 12.3 meters in length and up to 3.7 meters in height.\nWhile there is no direct evidence for Tyrannosaurus having feathers, many scientists now consider that it likely had feathers on at least some parts of its body, due to their presence in related species. Below is an artistic interpretation of the T. rex.

Velociraptor was a bipedal, feathered carnivore with a long tail and enlarged sickle-shaped claw on each hind foot. Like Tyrannosaurus, it is also one of the most familiar dinosaurs due to its prominent role in the “Jurassic Park” movie. In real life, however, Velociraptor was roughly the size of a turkey, considerably smaller than the approximately 2 m tall reptiles seen in the films. Also, real Velociraptors were feathered and warm blooded.

Spinosaurus was among the largest of all known carnivorous dinosaurs, possibly larger than Tyrannosaurus. It could grow up to 14.3 metres long and could weigh around 20 tonnes. It is known to have eaten fish, and most scientists believe that it hunted both terrestrial and aquatic prey. They lived both on land and in the water as modern crocodiles do.
Pachycephalosaurus was a bipedal herbivore with an extremely thick skull roof. Also it was one of the last living non-avian dinosaurs before the Cretaceous-Paleogene extinction.

Triceratops was a herbivorous dinosaur and one of the last known non-avian dinosaurs. It is estimated, that Triceratops could grow up to 9 meters in length, 3 meters in height and could weigh about 12 tonnes.

Ankylosaurus was a genus of the armored dinosaurs which was among the last of the surviving non-avian dinosaurs. Large individuals measured up to 6.25 meters in length, 1.7 meters in height and weighed 6 tonnes. Newly discovered fossils revealed, that some of the Ankylosaurus species had antipredator colorations, which evidence a high predator pressure towards the end of the Cretaceous.

Mosasaurus is an extinct carnivorous aquatic lizard which could grow up to 17 meters in length. It is believed, that it lived close to the ocean surface, where it preyed on fish, turtles, ammonites, smaller mosasaurs, birds, pterosaurs and plesiosaurs.

Ammonites is an extinct group of marine mollusc animals. They are excellent index fossils and appeared in the Devonian. They are mentioned here, because they are the most famous mollusc group extinct in the Cretaceous-Paleogene event.

Therizinosaurus cheloniformis was a large and unique dinosaur. At 10 meters in length and 5 tons in weight, they also had gigantic claws, longest known from any animal, sometimes reaching even 70 centimeters in length.
Tsintaosaurus had a characteristic “duck bill” snout and a battery of powerful teeth which were used to chew vegetation. It was about 10 meters long and 3.6 meters tall.

Deinocheirus was an unusual dinosaur, largest growing up to 11 meters long, and weighing 6.4 tonnes. It had a pair of large arms and probably was omnivorous. It used those long claws for digging and gathering plants. It is thought, that Deinocherus was a slow animal.

Quetzalcoatlus was a very large pterosaur and one of the largest known flying animals of all time. Its name comes from the Mesoamerican feathered serpent god, Quetzalcoatl. Its wingspan reached 10–11 meters and whole individual was at least 3 meters tall.

Giganotosaurus was a large dinosaur, similar or even larger than Tyrannosaurus. It lived in what is now Argentina. Like Tyrannosaurus, it had a metabolism intermediate between that of mammals and reptiles, and was able to sustain a stable body temperature.
Linhenykus is the only known a non-avian dinosaur to have a single digit. It was small-bodied and lived in what is now Mongolia. Although it looks like an ostrich, it is not related to them.

Sarcosuchus is an extinct genus of crocodyliform and distant relative of living crocodylians. It is one of the largest crocodile–like reptiles and it lived in what is now Africa and South America. It was almost twice as long (up to 11–12 m) as the modern saltwater crocodile and weighed up to 8 tonnes. They lived in freshwater environment and probably hunted both fish and terrestrial prey (like the Nile crocodiles do).

Microraptor was a genus of small, four-winged paravian dinosaurs. Their well-preserved fossils provide important evidence about the evolutionary relationship between birds and dinosaurs. It was among the most abundant non-avialan dinosaurs in its ecosystem. Adult specimens estimated up to 77 centimeters long and weighed up to 1 kilogram. Microraptor was an opportunistic predator, which hunted on small mammals, other bird-like dinosaurs and fish.
Titanoboa is the largest known snake, which could reach 13 meters in length and weigh up to 1.2 tonnes. It mostly fed on fish and lived in the Paleocenian tropics.

Gastornis were very large birds that lived during the Late Paleocene and Eocene. They could grow up to 2 metres in height and have traditionally been considered to be predators of small mammals. However, several lines of evidence, including the lack of hooked claws in known Gastornis footprints and studies of their beak structure have caused scientists to reinterpret these birds as herbivores that probably fed on tough plant material and seeds.

Basilosaurus is a genus of the early whales that lived in the Late Eocene. Unlike modern whales, Basilosaurus was an apex predator.\nBelow you can see the currently known transitional whale evolution forms.

Paraceratherium is an extinct genus of hornless rhinoceros and one of the largest terrestrial mammals that has ever existed. Its height was about 4.8 metres, and the length about 7.4 metres, and weight is estimated to have been 15 to 20 tonnes.

Daeodon is an extinct genus of artiodactyl (elks, boars, bisons etc. are artiodactyls too) that inhabited North America during the Late Oligocene and Early Miocene epochs. They were around 1.8 m tall at the shoulders and had skulls about 90 cm long.

Pyrotherium is an extinct mammal genus related to the modern ungulates (like pigs, cattle, deers), that lived in Argentina during the Early Oligocene. They could weigh up to 3500 kg and were about 1.5 metres tall.
Archaeotherium is an extinct animal related to the pigs, which lived in the modern North America. It was about 1.2 metres tall and weighed around 270 kg.

Arsinoitherium is an extinct mammal related to the modern elephants. They were rhinoceros-like herbivores that lived in the northern Africa, in areas of the tropical rainforest and at the margin of the mangrove swamps. Adult species stood around 1.75 meters tall.

Argentavis is among the largest flying birds ever to exist, having an estimated wing span of 5–6 meters, a height of 1.5–2 meters and a mass of approximately 70 kilograms. It probably preferred to scavenge for carrion.

Ardipithecus might be one of the earliest ancestors of humans after they diverged from the main ape lineage, although it is still a matter of debate. It was very similar to chimpanzees and lived in the territory of the modern Ethiopia. Ardipithecus had a small brain, measuring between 300 and 350 cm3. This is slightly smaller than a modern chimpanzee brain and roughly 20% the size of the modern human brain. Nevertheless, it is in some ways unlike chimpanzees, suggesting that the common ancestor differs from the modern chimpanzee. After the chimpanzee and human lineages diverged, both underwent substantial evolutionary change. Chimp feet are specialized for grasping trees; Ardipithecus feet are better suited for walking.

Carcharodon megalodon also known as megalodon is an extinct species of shark which lived almost until the end of the Neogene. It was one of the largest and most powerful predators in vertebrate history, reaching 18 metres in length. It is known, that they preyed on whales and fish. They extinct probably because of the multiple reasons, including the oceanic cooling, sea level drops and the decline in food supply.

Livyatan is an extinct whale, similar in size to the modern sperm whale. It reached almost 18 meters in length and had powerful functional teeth in both of its jaws. It was an apex predator along with the giant megalodon. Its extinction was likely caused by a cooling event at the end of the Miocene which resulted in a drop in food populations. The formations where the whale has been found have also preserved a large assemblage of marine life, such as sharks and marine mammals.

Titanis walleri is a large extinct flightless carnivorous bird, which lived in the North America. It was about 2.5 meters tall and weighed approximately 150 kilograms. It is one of the famous terror birds, which were dominant predators in the early Cenozoic and Middle Cenozoic era.

Deinotherium was a large prehistoric relative of the modern-day elephants. They differed only by a shorter trunk, and it had downward curling tusks attached to the lower jaw. They could grow up to 4 meters tall and weigh about 12 tonnes.
Platybelodon was a large herbivorous mammal related to the elephants. They lived in Asia and the Caucascus.

Stegotetrabelodon is an extinct primitive elephant with four tusks instead of two. They lived in Africa and were very similar to the modern elephants. Below is an artist interpretation, how it really could look like.
